reasoning: The critique targets Section 2.4’s load-bearing illustrative model: that future value behaves like a product of (roughly) independent factors, implying mostly-great futures are rare. If that specific independence-style multiplicative picture were wrong, some of the paper’s quantitative/intuition-building support for “eutopian fragility” would weaken, but the overall “no easy eutopia” thesis also has many other supports (historical moral catastrophes, diverse moral theories being ‘fussy’, bounded/unbounded value-function analysis), so centrality is moderate rather than decisive. As a countermodel, correlation/transfer of moral competence is a plausible and relevant challenge: if high performance on one dimension raises the conditional probability of high performance on others, then independence-based rarity claims can be overstated. However, it doesn’t fully refute the paper’s core claim because (i) multiplicative fragility can persist under correlation, (ii) the paper’s toy model is explicitly labeled a toy/illustrative distribution, and (iii) the broader argument for fussiness doesn’t rely solely on independence. The critique’s main factual/logical points are mostly correct, though it asserts “dramatically” without quantification. It is clear, focused, and has little dead weight.
title: Correlated moral competence across domains enlarges the target
